subtitle.en: Stock Options & RSUs Guide for Chinese Employees

disclaimer.en: Educational purposes only. Please consult with financial and tax professionals for personalized advice.

subtitle.en: Complete guide for Chinese employees working at foreign companies. Understand your stock compensation, tax implications, and make informed decisions.

description.en: Stock options give you the right (but not obligation) to buy company shares at a fixed price (strike price) for a certain period. If the company's stock price rises above your strike price, you can profit.

example.en: Example: You have options with a $10 strike price. If the stock trades at $50, you can buy at $10 and immediately sell at $50, making $40 per share profit. Wait wait, can you really get $40k in your pocket?

holding_period.en: Must hold 2+ years from grant, 1+ year from exercise

ordinary_income.en: Taxed as ordinary income when exercised

note.en: The ISO/NSO distinction commonly used in the US may not directly apply in China's context. Chinese companies typically structure their equity incentives based on local regulations and practical needs. For instance, many tech companies using VIE structures need to consider specific requirements around option exercise registration. While understanding ISO/NSO concepts is helpful, the actual implementation in China often requires customized solutions that work within the local regulatory framework. In practice, Chinese companies tend to favor NSO-like structures for their flexibility.

description.en: Most options vest over time, typically 4 years with a 1-year cliff:

note.en: The vesting schedule may vary depending on the company's policy. In previous years, stock options vested 25% annually over 4 years to reach 100%. However, in recent years, many companies have adopted more employee-friendly vesting schedules - for example, 25% after the first year, then vesting quarterly or monthly for the remaining three years to reach 100%. This design makes vesting more flexible and provides faster incentives for employees.

description.en: RSUs are company shares given to employees that vest over time. Unlike options, you don't pay to exercise them. When they vest, you automatically own the shares and owe taxes on their full market value. In China, only companies that have gone public can offer RSUs. For pre-IPO companies, only options can be granted. However, in other countries, some unicorn companies can also choose to directly grant RSUs to employees.

key_difference.en: Key Difference: With RSUs, you own actual shares once vested. With options, you have the right to buy shares at a specific price.

description.en: RSUs typically vest quarterly over 3-4 years
You owe income tax on the full market value when shares vest
Additional gains/losses when you sell are treated as capital gains

content.en: Tax laws are complex and change frequently. This is educational information only. Always consult with qualified tax professionals in both countries.

iso.en: ISO: No tax on exercise, but AMT may apply. Tax on sale based on holding period.

nso.en: NSO: Ordinary income tax on exercise (fair market value - strike price)

capital_gains.en: Capital gains tax on any additional gains when selling shares

vesting_tax.en: Ordinary income tax on vesting date (full market value)

sale_tax.en: Capital gains tax on gains/losses from vesting price to sale price

key_points.en: Key Points for Chinese Tax Residents:

worldwide_income.en: China may tax worldwide income, including stock compensation

tax_treaties.en: Tax treaties between US and China may provide relief from double taxation

timing_differences.en: Timing of recognition may differ between US and China tax systems

currency_conversion.en: Currency conversion rates affect the taxable amount in RMB

residency_rules.en: Different rules may apply based on your tax residency status

capital_gains_china.en: Capital gains from stock sales are subject to China's tax rates

complete_tax_chain.en: Complete tax implications from grant to final sale

tax_year.en: Consider tax year timing for exercises/sales

residency_changes.en: Plan around changes in tax residency

detailed_records.en: Keep detailed records of all transactions

exchange_rates.en: Track exchange rates on transaction dates

agreements.en: Maintain grant agreements and vesting schedules

ipo_soon.en: Company is likely to go public soon (lock in lower tax basis)

appreciation_expected.en: You believe stock price will appreciate significantly

holding_period.en: You want to start the capital gains holding period

amt_minimize.en: ISOs: Minimize AMT impact by exercising small amounts annually

liquidity_needs.en: Need liquidity and can't afford exercise cost

underwater.en: Stock price is below your strike price

expiration_risk.en: Approaching expiration but stock hasn't performed

description.en: Exercise and sell immediately
Exercise and hold for 1+ years
Sell portions over time

diversification_key.en: Diversification is Key: Don't put all your wealth in company stock, even if you're optimistic about its prospects.

total_exposure.en: Consider your total compensation exposure to company performance

target_percentages.en: Set target percentages for company stock in your portfolio

exit_strategy.en: Have an exit strategy before you need it

subtitle.en: Common abbreviations and terms used in stock compensation

description.en: Tax-advantaged stock options for employees with special holding period requirements
Stock options without special tax treatment, taxed as ordinary income
Company shares that vest over time, no exercise required
Program allowing employees to buy company stock at a discount
US tax calculation that may apply to ISO exercises
When a private company first sells shares to the public
The current trading price or estimated value of a stock
Tax rate for assets held longer than one year
Tax rate for assets held one year or less
Timeline over which you earn the right to your stock compensation
Initial waiting period before any options or shares vest
Fixed price at which you can buy shares through options
The act of buying shares using your stock options

options_description.en: Need to pay to exercise, higher risk but higher potential return

rsu_description.en: Automatically receive shares when vested, more convenient

description.en: Your exercise income will be taxed at progressive rates

taxable_income_formula.en: Taxable Income = Annual Income - 60,000 CNY basic deduction

marginal_rate_explanation.en: Option exercise income is taxed at marginal rates, i.e., additional tax burden on your current income

capital_gains_rate.en: Capital gains tax (when selling) is calculated at a fixed 20% rate

message.en: Given your high liquidity needs, exercising and selling options could provide immediate cash flow.
Pre-IPO companies often see significant gains. Consider holding if you can afford the risk.
With less than 1 year to expiration, consider exercising soon to avoid losing value.
Consider selling vested RSUs to meet liquidity needs and diversify your portfolio.
Mature companies may have limited upside. Consider selling to diversify investments.
Exercise costs may strain your finances. Consider cashless exercise or waiting for better liquidity.
Diversification is key. Don't put all your wealth in company stock, regardless of your optimism.

disclaimer.en: This is educational guidance only. Always consult with financial and tax professionals before making decisions.

subtitle.en: Learn about the basics of stock options, RSUs, and tax implications in our comprehensive guide.
